title: What were old computers from the 70’s and 80’s used for? - Quora

response.answer_text: I can’t speak to what all of them were used for, particularly the minicomputers and mainframes. My guess is the mainframes in the ’70s were used for what they had chiefly been used for since the 1950s, which was accounting. I remember in the 1980s seeing that they were used for storing large databases (my local library digitized their whole card catalog on one). Newspapers used them for typesetting their daily editions. Supercomputers were around in the ‘80s, and as far as I knew, they were used for running atmospheric models for research and weather prediction. As for microcomputers in the ‘70s, the only thing I remember them being used for was to run VisiCalc, which was the first spreadsheet, though Wordstar also existed, which was a word processor. In the ‘80s, that didn’t really change, at least in the professional sphere. Dbase was added to that, which was a relational database package for PCs. Businesses typically used it along with a word processor and spreadsheet, creating a suite. This was usually the way computers were used during that era. Eventually businesses added the local area network (LAN) to the mix, so people could share computer data without having to put it on floppy disk. Mind you, this was all on command-line systems. Computers with graphical interfaces came out in the mid-80s, but that didn’t become the standard way that people used computers until the ‘90s. Beginning in the early ‘80s, parents started buying microcomputers to do work at home. Some also bought them so their kids (typically their sons. From what I understand, parents tended to keep their daughters away from them) could use a word processor to write papers for school, and/or just a machine to play around on (probably to play video games). This was the time when a lot of budding programmers that have since started their own technology companies, or become software developers at the same, got their start, because it was expected that if you were going to use a computer, you’d learn to program it at least a little. It was difficult to do much else besides run software on them without learning to program them. Every computer (with the exception of the Apple Macintosh) came with a version of the Basic language, usually from Microsoft, and part of the user manual would have instructions telling the user about it, and introduce them to the language’s commands. Programming was also encouraged in the industry literature. Most computer magazines had program listings in them in Basic and assembly or machine language, at least from time to time, that readers could type in, and get some cheap software (for the price of the magazine). Starting in college (‘88), I could use my microcomputer from my dorm room or apartment to call up what were called bulletin board systems (BBSes), which were homebrew remote-access systems that people would set up in their homes, or for their store, which they would open up to the public. Typically only one person could call them up at a time, because they’d only have one phone modem hook-up, and most PCs were not set up for multitasking. This was one way I used to carry on online discussions with people, and get some public domain software for my computer. Online discussions were slow affairs, though, with BBSes. You’d write something one day, and not see a response until the next day, or a few days later. Since I was a computer science major, I also had access to the internet (starting in ‘89). It was a bit of a convoluted process, though, since I didn’t have direct access. I’d use my phone modem to connect to the school’s minicomputer systems, and access the internet from there. This way, I was able to do my programming assignments from home on the school’s computers, which was a good thing, because many of us CS majors didn’t have computers powerful enough to run all the different interpreters and compilers that we needed to get our assignments done. We got exposed to a bunch of different languages in CS then. By the late ‘80s, it was fairly common for students to write their school papers on word processors. That was starting to be the norm. It also seemed like schools were adopting the graphical user interface as their standard way of using computers, since Apple still dominated the education market, and after the Apple II, schools upgraded to Macintoshes.

OP: What were old computers from the 70’s and 80’s used for? I can’t add more than what Mark Miller, Chris Torkildson, Michael Lipphardt, and the others have already said, but thanks for the A2A. Your question covers a 20 year time span, so there were a huge amount of developments in computers during those decades. When comparing oranges to oranges (comparing apples might be confusing), the computers from 1989 were vastly improved over the computers of 1970. Computers in the 70s and 80s were pretty much used for the same things they are today, although with less processing speed, much lower resolution graphics (if they had graphics), less user-friendly interfaces, and at a significantly higher price tag. Computers calculated things from ballistic trajectories to animal populations, they simulated things from economic behavior to weather patters, we used them for word processing, spreadsheets, drafting, and even gaming. The main difference was in home use. In the 70s, almost no one had a computer at home; they were just too expensive unless your job demanded/paid for you to have one. As companies started cloning the IBM PC, prices dropped to the point that people could afford a computer at home. The Internet wasn’t anything like it is today, and was pretty much unknown to most people, so computers weren’t used for things we now take for granted like shopping and blogging—although you could order things direct from some companies using your computer, and you could post information to a variety of BBSs. If you really want to know more, I highly recommend looking at The Old Computer Museum, which has a timeline of important computers, and you should also look at The Computer History Museum, where you can explore several of their exhibits online. If you’re into nerdy pursuits like computers, be sure to stop by The Nerd Manual and check out my articles.

I used a PDP 8i on a daily basis from the mid 70s through early 90s. It ran an automated test system. I loved that thing. 12k of core memory. It had two (not just one!) 4k memory extenders! ASR33 teletype. Storage on 8 track type mag tape, not paper tape. We were the cats ass. I wrote in near machine language because, well, that was how it was done. DEC came in every three months and adjusted the memory clock speed and replaced burned out lamps on the front panel.   Yes sir, that's my baby. The grey sticker on the left is the octal code for the bootstrap loader. You keyed that in using the toggle switches (orange and white, the colors designating one octal digit) at the bottom. I had it memorized.

Somewhere in my basement is a Compaq Luggable from 1984 which to me was around the time when computers really began to be “useful” for office work. The machine was later replaced by its successor in 1987, the Compaq II Portable computer which was used for early automation of test and measurement equipment. I was never into games so those early machines were used primarily professionally although I did dabble with early MIDI stuff by interfacing it with an ancient KORG keyboard.

I can’t answer it quite accurately but one of my professor at university once told me that they use to run simulations of code in COBOL on their university systems in 1988 even though it was a lengthy and tiresome procedure but there wasn't another way to run those.Also multiple calculations (also scientific calculations as scientific calculators weren’t around) were done using a program. If you recall the first man sent in space : it was because of computers.Programming was a lot intense and lengthy and computing power was less than cell phones you carry around these days but still it was achieved.

In the 70s computers were largely limited to large institutions. For example banks could have computers that cold be used to determine the balance of an account from any office though o some banks they had to call those things but still there was a computer at some point involved. In the 70s many still ad bank books and you could not withdraw money without the book so the account always had at least as much as marked on the book. In the 80s the personal computers were introduced. They were used for things like word processing and spread sheets. Also home computers err introduced. Thy mainly were used for playing games though some also used them for programming stuff. By 1990 the separate home computer category had largely disappeared.

The Altair was used for programming, I think that even had a BASIC interpreter. Old computers were used for almost anything from programming, gaming, calculations, word processing, communication (with modems)
